text: Santiago de los Caballeros de Mérida, Venezuela, is the capital of the municipality of Libertador and the state of Mérida, and is one of the principal cities of the Venezuelan Andes. It was founded in 1558, forming part of Nueva Granada, but later became part of the Captaincy General of Venezuela, and played an active role in the War of Independence. Mérida has more than 200,000 inhabitants and a metropolitan area containing some 350,000 people. It is the main center for education and tourism in western Venezuela, the home of the prestigious University of the Andes, and the location of the highest and second longest aerial tramway in the world. Mérida is at an altitude of approximately 1,600 meters (5,249 ft). The city sits on a plain in the valley of the Chama river, which runs from one end to the other. The backdrop of Mérida's skyline is the country's highest summit, Pico Bolívar. ==Flag== Merida's flag represents the city and also the Libertador municipality. The flag is divided into 8 sections. Each section has a different color whose representation has not yet been revealed. In the center, the cross of Santiago is displayed in honor of the city by its official name, Santiago de los Caballeros de Mérida. ==Other websites== Category:Cities in Venezuela Category:Capitals of Venezuelan states Category:Mérida (state) Category:1550s establishments in South America Category:16th-century establishments in Venezuela
title: Mérida, Venezuela
